canonical_explanation.text:
Movement is one of the characteristic features of living organisms. It may be of different types: amoeboid, ciliary, flagellar, and muscular. Locomotion is the voluntary movement of an organism from one place to another. In humans, the locomotory system comprises the muscular system and the skeletal system. There are three types of muscles: skeletal (striated, voluntary), smooth (non-striated, involuntary), and cardiac (striated, involuntary). Skeletal muscles are attached to bones and are responsible for body movements. Each muscle fibre is a syncytium containing multiple nuclei. The myofibrils within each fibre show alternating dark (A band or anisotropic) and light (I band or isotropic) bands. The functional unit of contraction is the sarcomere, bounded by two Z lines, containing the central A band with the H zone and M line.

Muscle contraction follows the sliding filament theory: a nerve impulse at the neuromuscular junction releases acetylcholine, which triggers an action potential in the muscle fibre. Ca²⁺ is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, binds to troponin on actin filaments, causing tropomyosin to shift and expose active sites. Myosin heads bind to actin, forming cross-bridges, and pull the actin filaments towards the centre of the sarcomere using energy from ATP hydrolysis. This causes the I band and H zone to shorten while the A band remains unchanged. The human skeleton consists of 206 bones, divided into the axial skeleton (skull, vertebral column, ribs, sternum — 80 bones) and the appendicular skeleton (limb bones and girdles — 126 bones). Joints are classified as fibrous (immovable), cartilaginous (slightly movable), and synovial (freely movable). Disorders include myasthenia gravis, muscular dystrophy, tetany, osteoporosis, arthritis, and gout.
rules: Three types of muscles: skeletal (striated, voluntary), smooth (non-striated, involuntary), and cardiac (striated, involuntary with intercalated discs).
The sarcomere is the functional unit of muscle contraction, bounded by Z lines; it contains the A band (dark), I band (light), H zone, and M line.
During contraction, I bands and H zone shorten; the A band does not change in length.
Sliding filament theory: Ca²⁺ binds troponin → tropomyosin shifts → actin-myosin cross-bridges form → actin slides over myosin using ATP.
At the neuromuscular junction, the motor neuron releases acetylcholine, generating an action potential in the muscle fibre.
Ca²⁺ is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum; ATP is needed for both cross-bridge cycling and detachment of myosin heads.
The human skeleton has 206 bones: axial skeleton (80 bones) and appendicular skeleton (126 bones).
Axial skeleton includes the skull (22 bones), vertebral column (26 vertebrae), ribs (12 pairs), sternum, and hyoid bone.
Appendicular skeleton includes pectoral and pelvic girdles, and upper and lower limb bones.
Joints: fibrous (sutures in skull — immovable), cartilaginous (between vertebrae — slightly movable), synovial (knee, elbow — freely movable).
Synovial joints have subtypes: ball-and-socket (shoulder, hip), hinge (elbow, knee), pivot (atlas-axis), gliding (between carpals), and saddle (thumb).

Disorders: myasthenia gravis (autoimmune, weakened muscles), muscular dystrophy (progressive degeneration), osteoporosis (decreased bone density), arthritis (joint inflammation), gout (uric acid crystals in joints).

questions.question_text: Which type of muscle is both striated and involuntary?
questions.explanation_correct: Cardiac muscle is unique in being both striated (showing alternating dark and light bands) and involuntary (not under conscious control). It is found exclusively in the heart and contracts rhythmically throughout life.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Skeletal muscle is striated but voluntary. Smooth muscle (also called visceral muscle) is non-striated and involuntary. Only cardiac muscle combines the features of striation and involuntary control.

questions.question_text: Which of the following types of movement is exhibited by leucocytes (WBCs)?
questions.explanation_correct: Leucocytes exhibit amoeboid movement by forming pseudopodia. This allows them to squeeze through capillary walls and move to sites of infection. Macrophages in the immune system also show this type of movement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ciliary movement is seen in the tracheal epithelium and fallopian tubes. Flagellar movement is characteristic of spermatozoa. Muscular movement involves contraction of muscle fibres for locomotion.

questions.question_text: Each skeletal muscle fibre is a multinucleated structure known as a:
questions.explanation_correct: Each skeletal muscle fibre is a syncytium, meaning it is a single large cell formed by the fusion of many embryonic myoblasts, resulting in multiple nuclei within a common cytoplasm (sarcoplasm) enclosed by a single plasma membrane (sarcolemma).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sarcolemma is the plasma membrane of the muscle fibre. Sarcomere is the functional unit of contraction between two Z lines. Sarcoplasm is the cytoplasm of the muscle fibre. A syncytium refers to the multinucleated nature of the muscle fibre.

questions.question_text: Intercalated discs are characteristic features of:
questions.explanation_correct: Intercalated discs are specialised junctions found between adjacent cardiac muscle cells. They contain gap junctions and desmosomes that allow rapid transmission of electrical impulses from one cell to the next, enabling the heart to contract as a coordinated unit.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Skeletal muscle fibres are multinucleated syncytia without intercalated discs. Smooth muscle fibres are spindle-shaped uninucleate cells. Tendons are connective tissue structures that attach muscles to bones.

questions.question_text: A muscle that appears non-striated under the microscope and is found in the wall of the intestine would be classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: Smooth muscle (also called visceral or non-striated muscle) is found in the walls of hollow internal organs like the intestine, stomach, urinary bladder, and blood vessels. It lacks the striations seen in skeletal and cardiac muscles and is under involuntary control.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Skeletal and cardiac muscles are striated and would not appear non-striated under the microscope. Voluntary muscle is another name for skeletal muscle, which has clear striations and is not found in the intestinal wall.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly differentiates skeletal muscle from smooth muscle?

options.text: Skeletal muscle is uninucleate; smooth muscle is multinucleate
Skeletal muscle has striations and is voluntary; smooth muscle lacks striations and is involuntary
Skeletal muscle is found in the heart; smooth muscle is found in limbs
Skeletal muscle contracts slowly; smooth muscle contracts rapidly

questions.explanation_correct: Skeletal muscle is striated (showing alternating dark and light bands due to organised myofilaments) and is under voluntary control. Smooth muscle lacks striations (myofilaments are not organised in regular sarcomeres) and is involuntary.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Skeletal muscle is multinucleate (syncytium), not uninucleate. Cardiac muscle, not skeletal, is found in the heart. Skeletal muscle generally contracts rapidly while smooth muscle contracts slowly and sustains contraction.

questions.question_text: Ciliary movement in the human body is important in:

options.text: Movement of food through the oesophagus
Propulsion of the ovum through the fallopian tube

questions.explanation_correct: Ciliary movement is important in the fallopian tubes (oviducts), where the cilia of the epithelial lining help propel the ovum towards the uterus. Cilia also line the respiratory tract, where they move mucus and trapped particles upward.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Peristalsis (muscular contraction), not ciliary movement, moves food through the oesophagus. Blood movement in arteries is driven by cardiac output and arterial pressure. Bone movement at joints is caused by skeletal muscle contraction.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about cardiac muscle is incorrect?

options.text: Cardiac muscle fibres are branched and interconnected
Cardiac muscle shows rhythmic, involuntary contraction
Cardiac muscle cells communicate through intercalated discs

questions.explanation_correct: The statement that cardiac muscle lacks striations is incorrect. Cardiac muscle is striated, showing alternating light and dark bands similar to skeletal muscle. However, unlike skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle is involuntary and has intercalated discs for cell-to-cell communication.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cardiac muscle fibres are indeed branched and interconnected. They do show rhythmic, involuntary contractions driven by the pacemaker. They do communicate through intercalated discs containing gap junctions.

questions.question_text: Which protein covers the binding sites on actin filaments in a relaxed muscle?
questions.explanation_correct: In a relaxed muscle, tropomyosin covers the active binding sites on the actin filaments, preventing myosin heads from forming cross-bridges. When Ca²⁺ binds to troponin, it causes a conformational change that shifts tropomyosin, exposing the binding sites.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Troponin is a regulatory protein that binds Ca²⁺ and causes tropomyosin to shift, but it does not itself cover the binding sites. Myosin is the thick filament protein. Meromyosin refers to the fragments of myosin (heavy and light meromyosin).

questions.question_text: The red colour of certain skeletal muscles is due to the presence of:
questions.explanation_correct: Red muscle fibres contain a high concentration of myoglobin, an oxygen-binding protein similar to haemoglobin. Myoglobin stores oxygen and gives these muscles their reddish appearance. Red fibres are also rich in mitochondria and are adapted for sustained aerobic activity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Haemoglobin is found in red blood cells, not muscle fibres. Bilirubin is a bile pigment from haemoglobin breakdown. Cytochrome is an electron carrier in mitochondria. The red colour of muscle is specifically due to myoglobin.

questions.question_text: The functional unit of muscle contraction, bounded by two successive Z lines, is called the:
questions.explanation_correct: The sarcomere is the functional unit of muscle contraction. It extends from one Z line to the next Z line and contains the overlapping arrangement of thin (actin) and thick (myosin) filaments. During contraction, the sarcomere shortens.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A myofibril is a long chain of sarcomeres within a muscle fibre. The sarcoplasmic reticulum is a specialised endoplasmic reticulum that stores Ca²⁺. A motor unit is a motor neuron and all the muscle fibres it innervates.

questions.question_text: During muscle contraction, which of the following bands does NOT change in length?
questions.explanation_correct: The A band (anisotropic or dark band) does not change in length during muscle contraction because the thick myosin filaments that form it do not shorten. The I band, H zone, and the overall sarcomere length all decrease as actin slides over myosin.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The I band shortens as actin filaments slide inward. The H zone narrows or disappears as actin filaments overlap more with myosin. The sarcomere shortens overall. Only the A band remains unchanged.

questions.question_text: The neurotransmitter released at the neuromuscular junction to trigger muscle contraction is:
questions.explanation_correct: Acetylcholine (ACh) is the neurotransmitter released by motor neurons at the neuromuscular junction. It binds to receptors on the sarcolemma of the muscle fibre, generating an action potential that leads to the release of Ca²⁺ from the sarcoplasmic reticulum and muscle contraction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Noradrenaline is primarily a neurotransmitter of the sympathetic nervous system. Dopamine is involved in brain signalling pathways. Serotonin is associated with mood regulation. At the neuromuscular junction, only acetylcholine is released.

questions.question_text: Which ion is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum to initiate muscle contraction?
questions.explanation_correct: Ca²⁺ ions are released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum in response to an action potential. Ca²⁺ binds to troponin on the actin filaments, causing a conformational change that shifts tropomyosin and exposes the myosin-binding sites on actin, initiating contraction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Na⁺ and K⁺ are involved in generating action potentials along the sarcolemma but do not directly trigger the contractile mechanism. Mg²⁺ is a cofactor for ATPase activity. Ca²⁺ is the specific ion that initiates the sliding filament mechanism.

questions.question_text: According to the sliding filament theory, during muscle contraction:

options.text: Both actin and myosin filaments shorten
Actin filaments slide over myosin filaments towards the centre of the sarcomere
Myosin filaments slide over actin filaments
The Z lines move apart from each other

questions.explanation_correct: According to the sliding filament theory, neither actin nor myosin filaments shorten. Instead, the thin actin filaments slide over the thick myosin filaments towards the centre of the sarcomere (M line), causing the Z lines to move closer and the sarcomere to shorten.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Neither filament type shortens in length; they slide past each other. It is the actin that slides inward, not the myosin sliding outward. The Z lines move closer together during contraction, not apart.

questions.question_text: What is the role of ATP in muscle relaxation?

options.text: ATP causes Ca²⁺ release from sarcoplasmic reticulum
ATP is needed to detach myosin heads from actin and pump Ca²⁺ back into the sarcoplasmic reticulum
ATP binds to troponin and blocks the active sites
ATP is not required for muscle relaxation

questions.explanation_correct: ATP is essential for muscle relaxation. A fresh ATP molecule binds to the myosin head, causing it to detach from the actin filament. ATP is also required to actively pump Ca²⁺ back into the sarcoplasmic reticulum via Ca²⁺-ATPase, which allows tropomyosin to re-cover the binding sites.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ca²⁺ release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum initiates contraction, not relaxation. ATP does not bind to troponin. ATP is absolutely required for relaxation — this is why muscles become rigid (rigor mortis) after death when ATP is depleted.

questions.question_text: The correct sequence of events during muscle contraction is:

options.text: Neural signal → ACh release → Ca²⁺ release → Cross-bridge formation → Sliding of filaments
Ca²⁺ release → Neural signal → ACh release → Sliding of filaments → Cross-bridge formation
ACh release → Neural signal → ATP hydrolysis → Ca²⁺ release → Sliding of filaments
Cross-bridge formation → Neural signal → Ca²⁺ release → ACh release → Sliding of filaments

questions.explanation_correct: The correct sequence is: a neural signal (action potential) travels along the motor neuron → acetylcholine is released at the neuromuscular junction → action potential spreads along the sarcolemma → Ca²⁺ is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum → Ca²⁺ binds troponin → cross-bridges form → actin slides over myosin.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The neural signal must precede ACh release, which must precede Ca²⁺ release. Cross-bridge formation cannot occur before Ca²⁺ release. The sequence always begins with a neural signal from the motor neuron.

questions.question_text: Rigor mortis, the stiffening of muscles after death, occurs because:

options.text: ATP is no longer available to detach myosin heads from actin

questions.explanation_correct: After death, cellular metabolism stops and ATP production ceases. Without ATP, myosin heads cannot detach from actin filaments, and Ca²⁺ cannot be pumped back into the sarcoplasmic reticulum. The cross-bridges remain locked, causing the muscles to become stiff (rigor mortis).
questions.explanation_incorrect: While Ca²⁺ may leak from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, the primary cause of rigor mortis is the absence of ATP for cross-bridge detachment. Acetylcholine accumulation is not the cause. Decomposition occurs later and is a separate process.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about the sarcomere is correct?

options.text: The I band contains only thick myosin filaments
The A band contains both actin and myosin filaments in the overlap region
The H zone contains only actin filaments
The Z line is located at the centre of the A band

questions.explanation_correct: The A band (dark band) contains the entire length of the thick myosin filaments along with portions of the thin actin filaments that overlap with them. The overlap region within the A band is where cross-bridges form during contraction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The I band contains only thin actin filaments (no myosin). The H zone contains only thick myosin filaments (no actin overlap). The M line, not the Z line, is located at the centre of the A band. Z lines mark the boundaries of the sarcomere.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: The H zone and I band become narrower during muscle contraction.
Reason: Actin filaments slide towards the M line, increasing the overlap with myosin.

Select the correct option:

options.text: Both assertion and reason are true, and the reason correctly explains the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true, but the reason does not correctly explain the assertion
The assertion is true, but the reason is false

questions.explanation_correct: Both statements are true. During contraction, actin filaments slide inward towards the M line, increasing their overlap with myosin. This explains why the H zone (containing only myosin with no actin overlap) narrows or disappears, and the I band (containing only actin) narrows as more actin enters the A band region.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The assertion is factually correct — both H zone and I band shorten. The reason accurately describes the sliding filament mechanism that causes this change. Therefore, the reason correctly explains the assertion.

questions.question_text: The energy for the power stroke of the myosin head during muscle contraction is directly provided by:
questions.explanation_correct: The energy for the power stroke comes from the hydrolysis of ATP by myosin ATPase. ATP binds to the myosin head and is hydrolysed to ADP and Pi. The energy released cocks the myosin head into a high-energy position, and the release of Pi triggers the power stroke that pulls actin inward.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Creatine phosphate serves as a reserve energy source to regenerate ATP but does not directly power the cross-bridge cycle. GTP is not involved in muscle contraction. Ca²⁺ binding to troponin initiates contraction but does not provide energy for the power stroke.

questions.question_text: Which of the following structures stores calcium ions in a muscle fibre?
questions.explanation_correct: The sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) is a specialised form of smooth endoplasmic reticulum in muscle fibres that stores and releases Ca²⁺ ions. Upon stimulation, Ca²⁺ is released from the SR into the sarcoplasm, initiating muscle contraction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: T-tubules (transverse tubules) are invaginations of the sarcolemma that transmit action potentials deep into the fibre. The sarcolemma is the plasma membrane. Myofibrils are the contractile units. Only the sarcoplasmic reticulum stores Ca²⁺.

questions.question_text: The total number of bones in an adult human skeleton is:
questions.explanation_correct: An adult human skeleton consists of 206 bones. These are divided into the axial skeleton (80 bones, including skull, vertebral column, ribs, and sternum) and the appendicular skeleton (126 bones, including limb bones and girdles).
questions.explanation_incorrect: 200, 210, and 216 are incorrect. Infants have more than 206 bones, but many fuse during growth. The standard adult count as per NCERT is 206 bones.

questions.question_text: The axial skeleton includes all of the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation_correct: The pectoral (shoulder) girdle is part of the appendicular skeleton, not the axial skeleton. The axial skeleton consists of the skull, vertebral column (26 vertebrae), ribs (12 pairs), sternum, and hyoid bone — totalling 80 bones.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The skull, vertebral column, and sternum are all components of the axial skeleton. The pectoral girdle (consisting of the clavicle and scapula) belongs to the appendicular skeleton.

questions.question_text: Which type of joint allows free movement in various directions, as seen in the shoulder and hip?
questions.explanation_correct: Ball-and-socket joints, found at the shoulder and hip, allow movement in all directions — flexion, extension, abduction, adduction, rotation, and circumduction. The ball-shaped head of one bone fits into a cup-shaped socket of the adjacent bone.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fibrous joints (like skull sutures) are immovable. Cartilaginous joints (between vertebrae) allow limited movement. Hinge joints (elbow, knee) allow movement in only one plane (like a door hinge).

questions.question_text: The vertebral column in humans consists of how many vertebrae?
questions.explanation_correct: The adult vertebral column has 26 vertebrae: 7 cervical, 12 thoracic, 5 lumbar, 1 sacrum (5 fused), and 1 coccyx (4 fused). In childhood, there are 33 separate vertebrae, but the sacral and coccygeal vertebrae fuse in adults.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 22 is the number of skull bones. 33 is the number of vertebrae in children before fusion. 30 is not a standard count. The adult vertebral column has 26 bones after fusion of sacral and coccygeal vertebrae.

questions.question_text: The joint between the atlas and axis vertebrae is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: The joint between the atlas (C1) and axis (C2) vertebrae is a pivot joint. The odontoid process (dens) of the axis projects upward and fits into a ring on the atlas, allowing the head to rotate from side to side (as when shaking the head to say 'no').
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ball-and-socket joints (shoulder, hip) allow multiaxial movement. Hinge joints (elbow, knee) allow movement in one plane. Gliding joints (between carpals) allow sliding movements. The atlas-axis joint specifically allows rotational movement, making it a pivot joint.

questions.question_text: Which of the following pairs of bones forms the pectoral girdle?
questions.explanation_correct: The pectoral (shoulder) girdle is formed by two bones on each side: the clavicle (collar bone) anteriorly and the scapula (shoulder blade) posteriorly. It connects the upper limbs to the axial skeleton.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ilium and ischium are parts of the pelvic girdle. Humerus and radius are upper limb bones (arm and forearm). Femur and tibia are lower limb bones (thigh and leg). The pectoral girdle specifically comprises the clavicle and scapula.

questions.question_text: The joints between the flat bones of the skull are called:
questions.explanation_correct: Sutures are fibrous joints found between the flat bones of the skull. They are immovable (synarthrotic) joints where the bones are connected by dense connective tissue. Sutures allow for brain growth during childhood and fuse completely in adults.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Syndesmoses are fibrous joints with more connective tissue (e.g., between tibia and fibula). Symphyses are cartilaginous joints with a fibrocartilage pad (e.g., pubic symphysis). Synchondroses are cartilaginous joints with hyaline cartilage. Skull joints are specifically called sutures.

questions.question_text: How many pairs of ribs are present in the human body?
questions.explanation_correct: Humans have 12 pairs of ribs (24 ribs total). The first 7 pairs are true ribs (attached directly to the sternum), pairs 8-10 are false ribs (attached indirectly via costal cartilage), and pairs 11-12 are floating ribs (free at their anterior ends).
questions.explanation_incorrect: 10 and 14 pairs are incorrect counts. 24 refers to the total number of individual ribs, not the number of pairs. The human skeleton has 12 pairs of ribs.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is correctly matched?

options.text: Hinge joint — Between carpals of the wrist

questions.explanation_correct: The saddle joint at the base of the thumb (carpometacarpal joint) allows movement in two planes — back and forth and side to side — giving the thumb its characteristic opposability. The articulating surfaces are saddle-shaped.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gliding joints (not hinge) are found between carpals. The elbow is a hinge joint (not gliding). The knee is primarily a hinge joint (not pivot). The pivot joint is found between the atlas and axis vertebrae.

questions.question_text: The pelvic girdle is formed by the fusion of which three bones on each side?
questions.explanation_correct: The pelvic girdle (os coxae or hip bone) on each side is formed by the fusion of three bones: the ilium (uppermost and largest), the ischium (lower and posterior), and the pubis (lower and anterior). These fuse at the acetabulum, which articulates with the head of the femur.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Scapula and clavicle form the pectoral girdle, and the humerus is an upper limb bone. Femur, patella, and tibia are lower limb bones. Atlas, axis, and sacrum are parts of the vertebral column.

questions.question_text: The number of bones in the axial skeleton of an adult human is:
questions.explanation_correct: The axial skeleton consists of 80 bones: 22 skull bones, 1 hyoid, 26 vertebrae, 24 ribs, and 1 sternum (with 3 parts — manubrium, body, and xiphoid process). This total equals 80 bones in the axial skeleton.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 60 is too low. 120 and 126 are incorrect — 126 is the number of bones in the appendicular skeleton (upper and lower limbs plus girdles). The axial skeleton has 80 bones.

questions.question_text: Myasthenia gravis is a disorder characterised by:

options.text: Weakening of muscles due to an autoimmune attack on acetylcholine receptors

questions.explanation_correct: Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disorder in which antibodies attack acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction. This impairs signal transmission from nerves to muscles, leading to progressive weakness and fatiguability of skeletal muscles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Progressive degeneration of skeletal muscles describes muscular dystrophy. Inflammation of joints is arthritis. Decreased bone density is osteoporosis. Myasthenia gravis specifically involves autoimmune destruction of ACh receptors.

questions.question_text: Osteoporosis is a condition in which:

options.text: Bone mass and density decrease, making bones fragile
Joints become stiff due to uric acid deposits

questions.explanation_correct: Osteoporosis is a degenerative bone disease in which bone mass and density decrease due to excessive bone resorption. The bones become porous, brittle, and prone to fractures. It is more common in postmenopausal women due to decreased oestrogen levels.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Excessive bone thickening is not osteoporosis. Uric acid deposits in joints cause gout, not osteoporosis. Progressive muscle wasting is muscular dystrophy. Osteoporosis specifically involves decreased bone density.

questions.question_text: Gout is caused by the accumulation of which substance in the joints?
questions.explanation_correct: Gout is caused by the accumulation of uric acid crystals (sodium urate) in the joints, particularly in the toes and fingers. This leads to inflammation, swelling, and intense pain. It results from elevated blood uric acid levels (hyperuricaemia).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Calcium oxalate crystals form kidney stones, not gout. Cholesterol is associated with atherosclerosis. Lactic acid accumulates in muscles during anaerobic exercise but does not cause gout. Uric acid is the specific causative agent of gout.

questions.question_text: Arthritis refers to the:
questions.explanation_correct: Arthritis is the inflammation of one or more joints, causing pain, swelling, stiffness, and reduced range of motion. Common types include osteoarthritis (wear and tear of cartilage) and rheumatoid arthritis (autoimmune).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Inflammation of muscles is myositis. Degeneration of nerves is neuropathy. Excessive bone growth is not arthritis. The term 'arthritis' literally means inflammation of joints (arthro = joint, itis = inflammation).

questions.question_text: A patient shows progressive weakness and wasting of skeletal muscles. The condition is genetic and caused by the degeneration of muscle fibres. The most likely disorder is:
questions.explanation_correct: Muscular dystrophy is a group of genetic disorders characterised by progressive degeneration and weakening of skeletal muscles. It is caused by mutations in genes responsible for muscle structure and function (e.g., dystrophin gene in Duchenne muscular dystrophy).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Myasthenia gravis is autoimmune (not genetic degeneration of fibres) and involves ACh receptor destruction. Osteoporosis affects bones, not muscles. Tetany involves sustained muscle contraction due to low calcium levels, not progressive wasting.

questions.question_text: Tetany is caused by:

options.text: Low calcium levels in the blood leading to sustained muscle contractions

questions.explanation_correct: Tetany is caused by abnormally low levels of calcium in the blood (hypocalcaemia). Calcium is essential for regulating muscle contraction and nerve impulse transmission. Low calcium leads to increased nerve excitability and sustained, involuntary muscle contractions (spasms).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Excess calcium would not cause tetany. Clostridium tetani causes tetanus (lockjaw), which is different from tetany. Excess uric acid in joints causes gout. Tetany is specifically due to hypocalcaemia.

questions.question_text: Which of the following disorders is correctly matched with its cause?

options.text: Gout — Accumulation of calcium in bones
Myasthenia gravis — Autoimmune attack on ACh receptors at NMJ

questions.explanation_correct: Myasthenia gravis is correctly matched — it is an autoimmune disorder where antibodies destroy acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, leading to impaired nerve-to-muscle signalling and muscle weakness.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Osteoporosis is caused by decreased bone density, not autoimmune muscle destruction. Gout is caused by uric acid crystal accumulation in joints, not calcium in bones. Arthritis is joint inflammation, not specifically caused by vitamin D deficiency.

questions.question_text: A middle-aged woman after menopause is diagnosed with a condition where her bones fracture easily upon minor impact. The doctor recommends calcium and vitamin D supplements. The condition is most likely:
questions.explanation_correct: The symptoms — postmenopausal woman, easy fractures, treatment with calcium and vitamin D — are characteristic of osteoporosis. After menopause, decreased oestrogen levels accelerate bone loss, reducing bone density and making bones fragile.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune joint inflammation, not characterised primarily by fragile bones. Gout involves uric acid crystals in joints. Muscular dystrophy affects muscles, not bones.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about muscular dystrophy is correct?

options.text: It is caused by bacterial infection of muscles
It is a genetic disorder leading to progressive degeneration of skeletal muscles
It can be cured by administration of acetylcholine

questions.explanation_correct: Muscular dystrophy is a group of inherited genetic disorders that cause progressive weakness and degeneration of the skeletal muscles used during voluntary movement. The most common type, Duchenne muscular dystrophy, is caused by a mutation in the dystrophin gene.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Muscular dystrophy is genetic, not caused by bacterial infection. Acetylcholine administration treats myasthenia gravis, not muscular dystrophy. It primarily affects skeletal muscles, not smooth muscles.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: Osteoarthritis is more common in elderly people.
Reason: With ageing, the cartilage covering the bone surfaces at joints wears away, leading to bone-on-bone friction.

Select the correct option:

options.text: Both assertion and reason are true, and the reason correctly explains the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true, but the reason does not correctly explain the assertion
The assertion is true, but the reason is false

questions.explanation_correct: Both statements are true. Osteoarthritis is indeed more prevalent in elderly individuals because the articular cartilage that cushions the bone surfaces at joints gradually wears away with age and use. This leads to bone-on-bone friction, causing pain, stiffness, and inflammation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The assertion is true — osteoarthritis is an age-related degenerative joint disease. The reason accurately explains the mechanism (cartilage wear). Therefore, both are true and the reason correctly explains the assertion.

questions.question_text: The smallest bone in the human body is the:
questions.explanation_correct: The stapes (stirrup) is the smallest bone in the human body. It is one of the three ear ossicles (malleus, incus, stapes) located in the middle ear. It transmits sound vibrations from the incus to the oval window of the cochlea.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The hyoid is a small bone in the neck but larger than the stapes. The patella (kneecap) is the largest sesamoid bone. The coccyx is formed by 4 fused vertebrae. The stapes is the smallest bone at about 3 mm.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a part of the appendicular skeleton?
questions.explanation_correct: The sternum (breastbone) is part of the axial skeleton, not the appendicular skeleton. The axial skeleton includes the skull, vertebral column, ribs, and sternum. The appendicular skeleton includes the limb bones (humerus, femur, radius, etc.) and girdles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Humerus (upper arm bone), femur (thigh bone), and radius (forearm bone) are all part of the appendicular skeleton. Only the sternum belongs to the axial skeleton.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly describes the relationship between tendons and ligaments?

options.text: Tendons connect muscles to bones; ligaments connect bones to bones
Tendons connect bones to bones; ligaments connect muscles to bones
Both are made of elastic cartilage

questions.explanation_correct: Tendons are tough bands of dense connective tissue (mainly collagen fibres) that attach muscles to bones, transmitting the force of contraction. Ligaments are also connective tissue bands but they connect bone to bone at joints, providing stability.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tendons and ligaments have distinct functions and should not be confused. Tendons attach muscle to bone, not bone to bone. Both are made of dense connective tissue (collagen), not elastic cartilage.

questions.question_text: The thin filaments in a sarcomere are composed of:
questions.explanation_correct: The thin filaments are composed of three proteins: actin (the main structural protein forming F-actin), troponin (a regulatory protein with three subunits that binds Ca²⁺), and tropomyosin (a regulatory protein that covers the myosin-binding sites on actin in the resting state).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Myosin forms the thick filaments, not thin filaments. The thin filaments are not made of actin alone — troponin and tropomyosin are essential regulatory proteins. The thick filaments are composed of myosin.

questions.question_text: The cartilaginous joint between two adjacent vertebral bodies is called:
questions.explanation_correct: The joints between adjacent vertebral bodies are symphyses, a type of cartilaginous joint. An intervertebral disc made of fibrocartilage lies between the vertebrae, allowing slight movement and acting as a shock absorber.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sutures are fibrous joints in the skull. Gomphosis is a specialised fibrous joint (tooth in socket). Synchondrosis is a cartilaginous joint with hyaline cartilage (e.g., epiphyseal plates). The intervertebral joints are symphyses.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the correct order of structures from the outermost to the innermost in a skeletal muscle?
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order from outermost to innermost is: Epimysium (covers the entire muscle) → Perimysium (covers each fascicle/bundle of muscle fibres) → Endomysium (covers each individual muscle fibre). This hierarchical arrangement provides structural support and organisation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The endomysium is the innermost layer covering individual fibres, not the outermost. The perimysium is an intermediate layer covering fascicles. The epimysium is always the outermost connective tissue sheath.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the primary difference between osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis?

options.text: Osteoarthritis is an autoimmune disease; rheumatoid arthritis is due to wear and tear
Osteoarthritis is due to degeneration of cartilage; rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune inflammatory disease
Both are caused by bacterial infections
Osteoarthritis only affects fingers; rheumatoid arthritis only affects knees

questions.explanation_correct: Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease caused by the wearing away of articular cartilage, commonly in weight-bearing joints. Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune disorder where the immune system attacks the synovial membrane, causing chronic inflammation, pain, and joint deformity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The causes are reversed in option A. Neither is caused by bacterial infection. Both types of arthritis can affect multiple joints throughout the body, not just specific locations.
